author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Pointer): add new event for giving pointer end position

A new `PointerDestinationSet` event is now emitted when the pointer
beam is deactivated and the event payload now contains the world
position of the pointer tip which can be used to determine the position
in the world where the pointer was hitting.

This can be useful for determining where to teleport a player to by
listening to this new event and using the tip position variable to
move the player position to.

The accompanying example script has been updated to show this event.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Interaction): rename ObjectGrab to something more generic

The previous `ObjectGrab` script is going to be doing more than
just grabbing objects. It will be the place for any controller/object
interaction so a more appropriate name has been given to it.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Interaction): rename the using a door example

To be consistent with other examples, it's now just prefixed with
`Controller` as the `ControllerInteract` script no longer exists so
this prefix no longer is relevant.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Pointer): add play area cursor option to all pointers

The World Pointer abstract class now generates a play area cursor
that can be projected on to the end of any cursor that extends it.

The play area cursor can also handle collisions on the cursor end and
determine if the play area will be obstructed by other objects within
the cursor location. This can then be used to prevent teleporting
which will prevent players being in locations that they can clip into
objects.

The Simple Pointer and Bezier Pointer have been refactored so their
code that is the same between the two classes now sits in the World
Pointer class (as it's generic to all pointers). This provides the
two child pointers with more default parameters that are generic to
all child pointers as well.

The `Interfaces` directory has been renamed to `Abstractions` as the
World Pointer class isn't actually an interface so made no sense
calling the containing directory `Interfaces`.

A custom shader has been written to allow for Unlit Transparent colours
which work well with the pointers.

An example has been added that shows how the play area with collision
can be used to prevent players from teleporting to locations that would
mean they have the potential to walk into objects.
files_changed: 012_Controller_PointerWithAreaCollision.unity; 012_Controller_PointerWithAreaCollision.unity.meta; SteamVR_ControllerPointerEvents_ListenerExample.cs; Abstractions.meta; SteamVR_WorldPointer.cs; SteamVR_WorldPointer.cs.meta; SteamVR_WorldPointer.cs; Shaders.meta; Unlit_TransparentColor.shader; Unlit_TransparentColor.shader.meta; SteamVR_BezierPointer.cs; SteamVR_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs; SteamVR_SimplePointer.cs; GraphicsSettings.asset; README.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Controller): move haptic feedback to controller actions

The `SteamVR_ControllerActions` is a more appropriate place to initiate
an effect on the controller as it calls an action for the controller to
do such as vibrate or show/hide it's model.

A new example scene has been added to demonstrate the haptic rumble.
files_changed: 016_Controller_HapticRumble.unity; 016_Controller_HapticRumble.unity.meta; Breakable_Cube.cs; Breakable_Cube.cs.meta; Sword.cs; Sword.cs.meta; SteamVR_ControllerActions.cs; SteamVR_ControllerEvents.cs; README.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Movement): add ability to change play area Y on mesh colliders

It is now possible to move up and down mesh colliders by walking in
the play area and the mesh below will affect the Y of the play area.

It has an adverse effect of not doing the blink on fast movements
such as falling from a mesh because it's not an actual teleport but
a walk within game space.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(CameraRig): add ability to move camera rig with touchpad

The touchpad can now be used to move the play area in the direction
the headset is facing. It can also be used to strafe left and right
in the current facing direction.

The new `SteamVR_TouchpadWalking` script is added to the `[CameraRig]`
prefab and adds a box collider and a rigidbody to the camera rig to
handle collisions.

If the `SteamVR_HeadsetCollisionFade` script is also applied to the
`[CameraRig]->Camera` then on collision of the headset with a game
object, the user will have their position reset to their last good
known position. To achieve this a new `HeadsetCollisionDetect` event
has been added to the Headset Collision Fade script which the new
Touchpad Walking script listens for.

A big thanks to Reddit user `u/MisterDeum` for all the help with
testing this feature and coming up with ideas to make it a decent
feature to add to the toolkit.

A new example scene has been added to demonstrate this feature.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(CameraRig): add movement deadzone to prevent walking glitch

The Touchpad Walking script had an issue where the speed variable
would not completely reset after releasing the touchpad meaning the
CameraRig would slide slowly across the floor as a value was still
present. This fix adds a deadzone margin to zero the speed variable
if it falls between this margin to prevent the sliding effect.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Controllers): add listeners to controllers when they are turned on

Previously, the listeners on the controllers for teleporting and
touchpad walking would only register if the controllers were on and
tracking at the point the game started. If a new controller was
connected (or an existing controller disconnected then reconnected)
the listeners would not be added to that controller.

This fix listens for the `device_connected` event on the controllers
and adds the listener to that controller when it is found. If the
controller is disconnected, the event isn't removed as it will be
valid when the device is reconnected.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(CameraRig): extract user rigidbody out of touchpad walking

The Touchpad Walking script no longer is responsible for generating the
collider and rigidbody around the user. This logic is now in it's own
script called `SteamVR_PlayerPresence` which is used to create the
collider and rigidbody and can be used independently with other use
cases for this feature. The Touchpad Walking script requires the
Player Presence script to be attached to the CameraRig as well for it
to function.

A new method for locating the controllers has been added rather than
looking for game objects with a controller script on. Now, the
controller event `device_connected` is listened to and on connection
the appropriate listeners are registered.

A new helper class called `DeviceFinder` has been added to handle
getting script reference points for connected devices.

The Basic Teleport script has also been updated to utilise this new
method of controller location to ensure a consistent solution.
files_changed: DeviceFinder.cs; DeviceFinder.cs.meta; SteamVR_BasicTeleport.cs; SteamVR_ControllerEvents.cs; SteamVR_PlayerPresence.cs; SteamVR_PlayerPresence.cs.meta; SteamVR_TouchpadWalking.cs; README.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Structure): rename class prefix to `VRTK_`

Previously, the class prefix was `SteamVR_` however, this prefix is
confusing as it is the same as the official SteamVR Unity plugin
script prefix. It could also cause issues in the future with script
name conflicts. It's better to have a unique script name for this
toolkit.
files_changed: ArrowNotch.cs; ArrowSpawner.cs; BowAim.cs; Controller_Menu.cs; Gun.cs; Lamp.cs; LightSaber.cs; Menu_Color_Changer.cs; Menu_Container_Object_Colors.cs; Menu_Object_Spawner.cs; Openable_Door.cs; RC_Car_Controller.cs; Sphere_Spawner.cs; Sword.cs; VRTK_ControllerEvents_ListenerExample.cs; VRTK_ControllerEvents_ListenerExample.cs.meta; VRTK_ControllerInteract_ListenerExample.cs; VRTK_ControllerInteract_ListenerExample.cs.meta; VRTK_ControllerPointerEvents_ListenerExample.cs; VRTK_ControllerPointerEvents_ListenerExample.cs.meta; Whirlygig.cs; VRTK_WorldPointer.cs; VRTK_WorldPointer.cs.meta; VRTK_BasicTeleport.cs; VRTK_BasicTeleport.cs.meta; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs.meta; VRTK_ControllerActions.cs; VRTK_ControllerActions.cs.meta; VRTK_ControllerEvents.cs; VRTK_ControllerEvents.cs.meta; VRTK_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs; VRTK_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs.meta; VRTK_HeightAdjustTeleport.cs; VRTK_HeightAdjustTeleport.cs.meta; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs.meta; VRTK_InteractTouch.cs; VRTK_InteractTouch.cs.meta; VRTK_InteractUse.cs; VRTK_InteractUse.cs.meta; VRTK_InteractableObject.cs; VRTK_InteractableObject.cs.meta; VRTK_PlayerPresence.cs; VRTK_PlayerPresence.cs.meta; VRTK_SimplePointer.cs; VRTK_SimplePointer.cs.meta; VRTK_TouchpadWalking.cs; VRTK_TouchpadWalking.cs.meta; README.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Headset): move headset finding code to helper class

As the code to find the headset changes between unity versions, it's
better to have this call in a generic location rather than in
specific instances of code that require access to the headset.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): store highlight colors with a dictionary

Previously, the object highlight colours and original colours were
stored in a simple array, which could get out of sync if child objects
were added or removed from the interactable object.

The new dictionary method now stores the name of each child object
with their associated colour to prevent sync issues from occuring.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Interaction): move rigidbody creation from grab to touch

The Interact Touch script is now responsible for creating the
controller rigidbody as it can now also be toggled on or off via a
public method, meaning a grab action isn't required to toggle the
rigidbody state.

The Interact Grab can still toggle the rigidbody, so the exist
methods are unchanged and still work as they previously did.

The rigidbody colliders also are constructed out of boxes to better
fit the shape of the controller rather than a simple sphere.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
refactor(Pointer): use deltaTime to calculate activate delay

Previously, the activate delay countdown was worked out by using a
frame multiplier to simulate seconds. It's better to just use the
`Time.deltaTime` to work out roughly seconds passed.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(code): remove unused variables to remove warnings

A number of unused variables were throwing warnings in the editor.
These variables have now been removed as they are not in use.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Controller): rename controller events methods to make more sense

The Controller Events methods and parameters have been updated to use
better terminology when describing the controller interactions such
as button presses and releases. They are no longer referred to as
clicked/unclicked instead are now referred to as pressed/released.
files_changed: Controller_Menu.cs; RC_Car_Controller.cs; Sphere_Spawner.cs; VRTK_ControllerEvents_ListenerExample.cs; VRTK_WorldPointer.cs; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs; VRTK_ControllerEvents.cs; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs; VRTK_InteractUse.cs; VRTK_SimplePointer.cs; VRTK_TouchpadWalking.cs

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): add delay time for collision pausing on grab

Previously, the `Pause Collisions On Grab` was a boolean and always
paused for `0.2f` delay, which was very limiting. The variable has
been renamed to `On Grab Collision Delay` and allows a float to be
entered which determines the amount of time to disable the
collisions on the object being grabbed.

The example scenes have been updated to pause certain object collision
when they are required.

author: Brian Dean Jennings
message:
feat(Interaction): add RequireComponents to grab and touch

Since InteractGrab and InteractTouch don't work unless certain
components are a part of the controller, the RequireComponent
attributes will make sure those components are there or automatically
add them. They also keep required components from being removed in
the Unity editor.

author: Tim Kankelfitz
message:
feat(RoomExtender): add a script to move camera rig

This script allows the playArea to move with the player.
The CameraRig is only moved when at the edge of a defined circle.
Aims to create a virtually bigger play area.
I have added a demo scene to test the script
(028_CameraRig_RoomExtender).

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): remove physics glitch on rotation when grabbing

Previously, the controller was reset to a default rotation when an
item was grabbed and the item needed rotating. This caused a
physics glitch with the item being grabbed.

Now, the controller isn't rotated, but it's rotation is used to
determine the correct rotation for the object.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Interaction): remove rotation snap grab snap type

The Rotation Snap is redundant as the Handle Snap is a far better
solution to the problem. The Rotation Snap Grab Snap Type and the
Snap To Position and Snap To Rotation parameters have been removed.

All of the example scenes that used Rotation Snap have now been
updated to use Handle Snap.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Interaction): remove grab snap type parameter

As the `Rotation_Snap` has been removed, it makes little sense to have
a dedicated paramter to determine snap type as this can be inferred by
the two new parameters that have been added.

The `Precision Snap` checkbox determines if a Precision grab snap type
should be used and grabs the object at the point of contact without
adjusting the position or rotation of the object.

The `Right Hand Snap` and `Left Hand Snap` are now used to determine
if the object should be snapped to a specific position and rotation
within the controller. If a `Right Hand Snap` is present then when
the right hand controller picks up the object, this snap point will
be used. The same is true for the left hand controller and the
`Left Hand Snap` point. If neither snap points are provided then
the object is grabbed from the centre (the same as the old
`Simple Snap`).

This cleans up the parameter choices making it easier to understand.

The example scenes have been updated to reflect these changes.
files_changed: 014_Controller_SnappingObjectsOnGrab.unity; 016_Controller_HapticRumble.unity; 017_CameraRig_TouchpadWalking.unity; 021_Controller_GrabbingObjectsWithJoints.unity; 023_Controller_ChildOfControllerOnGrab.unity; 026_Controller_ForceHoldObject.unity; 028_CameraRig_RoomExtender.unity; Ball.prefab; BasicArrow.prefab; VRTK_Knob.cs; VRTK_Lever.cs; VRTK_Slider.cs; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs; VRTK_InteractableObject.cs; README.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): improve object tracking on track object mechanic

The `Grab Attach Mechanic` for `Track Object` now tracks very close to
1:1 ratio of the controller movements. It is also possible to add drag
to the rotational movements by lowering the `maxAngularVelocity` on
the Interactable Object's rigidbody, any number between 1 and 14 seems
to have a different drag effect.

Kudos to the NewtonVR team for making these fixes in their repo at:
`https://github.com/TomorrowTodayLabs/NewtonVR`

and to [zite](https://github.com/zite) for his work on NewtonVR.

The `Track Object` mechanic now also correctly uses the snap handles
on the Interactable Object.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Controls): remove warnings from unused variables

A few variables are declared but never used so they create warnings
in the editor. These variables have been removed as they are not
currently being used.

The `OnPopulateMesh(Mesh m)` method has also had the `Obsolete`
attribute applied to it to supress the warning it throws.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Pointer): clean up pointer artifacts on destroy

The pointers create game objects and register listeners and now when
a pointer script is destroyed it cleans up these created artifacts
by removing them.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
refactor(identification): determine player objects with script

Previously, player objects were identified by the name of the game
object. This was done by certain scripts would rename the game object
and add the string `PlayerObject` which would then be looked up by
other scripts.

This was not an ideal solution as it meant renaming game objects which
could create confusion and mess in the editor at runtime. It's cleaner
and more extensible to add a custom script to these objects and they
are identified by the existence of the script.

The `VRTK_PlayerObject` script also allows to hint at what type of
object it is from the following types:

  * CameraRig
  * Headset
  * Controller
  * Pointer
files_changed: VRTK_WorldPointer.cs; Utilities.cs; VRTK_PlayerObject.cs; VRTK_PlayerObject.cs.meta; VRTK_BasicTeleport.cs; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs; VRTK_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs; VRTK_InteractTouch.cs; VRTK_PlayerPresence.cs; VRTK_SimplePointer.cs; VRTK_TouchpadWalking.cs

author: Robert Wetzold
message:
feat(Interaction): add chest UI control

This change adds the chest as a new 3D control. The control will
add physics and events to a set of three game objects making up a chest.
Extensive auto-detection, editor visualization and default
events are supported.

Due to improvements in rotation handling buttons visualize rotations
better as well. Error gizmos are more useful. All controls were also
moved into the 3D folder.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(CameraRig): support default SteamVR prefab

It is now possible to use the default SteamVR `[CameraRig]` prefab and
the relevant dependencies on the prefab should now be set up at runtime
via the relevant scripts.

The custom `[CameraRig]` prefab has been removed and all example scenes
have been updated to use the default SteamVR `[CameraRig]` prefab.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Example): rename radial menu example for consistency

The Radial Touchpad Menu example scene has been renamed to keep it
more consistent with other Controls examples.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Presence): fix crash on object grab if no collider is present

The Player Presence script checks to see if a grabbed object has a
collider so it can ignore collisions with grabbed objects. However,
if the grabbed object doesn't have a collider but it's children do
then it would crash. This fix prevents that and checks for child
colliders to remove the physics collisions from.

author: Robert Wetzold
message:
fix(Interaction): react to enablement state of interactable_object

So far disabling an interactable_object at runtime did not have any
effect as it could still be touched and grabed. This patch checks the
enablement state explicitly.

A fix in the sample scene was needed to remove a boxcollider which
made it nearly impossible to showcase the feature that disables the
drawer contents.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Structure): remove incorrectly commited code

This code should never have been commited so it is being deleted.
This is being deleted via a commit rather than rebased out to
ensure other forks of the project do not break.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(utility): remove unrequired variable

The logs List variable is not used so it has been removed.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(RadialMenu): ensure events are de-registered on disable

The radial menu events are now set up on object enable and they are
removed when the object is disabled to allow for multiple radial
menus to work on the same controller.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Pointer): ensure pointer is cleaned up correctly on disable

When the pointer script is disabled it now removes any traces of
game objects and events that were created in the `OnEnable` code.

This means pointers can be enabled/disabled at runtime and keep
the scene clean of artifacts.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Pointer): remove unrequired eventsRegistered variable

The `eventsRegistered` variable is no longer required as the event
registration is handled in the `OnEnabled` method.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Structure): move helper scripts to helper directory

The `VRTK_ControllerTooltips.cs` and `VRTK_ObjectTooltip.cs` scripts
are not directly used by a developer and are utilised only by the
relevant prefabs, therefore the scripts should be in the Helper
directory instead of the main scripts directory.

author: Robert Wetzold
message:
feat(Testing): add movement simulator

For many trivial tests one still has to put on the headset in order to
move to the right spot. This increases turn-around times. This script
can be put onto the camera rig and will then allow movement through
the scene using keys. Once at the desired location the controllers can
be used to interact while looking at the monitor.

Supported so far are move, strafe, rotate and up/down. Being an early
version this is only tested in one context so far and especially after
rotating the move directions are inverted currently. These are all
things to look at in future versions. Help always welcome.

author: OmegaJak
message:
feat(RadialMenu): allow anchoring to interactable GameObjects

This is a combination of 6 commits. Their messages follow.

* feat(RadialMenu): add option to execute button on unclick
* fix(RadialMenu): fix not registering initial touch position
* refactor(RadialMenu): make RadialMenuController more extendible
* feat(RadialMenu): add support for anchoring to interactable objects
* refactor(RadialMenu): change prefab for easier use
* fix(RadialMenu): update executeOnUnclick to work with separate commit

Added haptic pulses, other minor fixes
files_changed: 030_Controls_RadialTouchpadMenu.unity; RadialMenu.prefab; RadialMenu.cs; VRTK_IndependentRadialMenuController.cs; VRTK_IndependentRadialMenuController.cs.meta; RadialMenuController.cs; Utilities.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Robert Wetzold
message:
feat(Interaction): service pack for 3D controls

This patch is the result of adapting the first set of controls to a
real game scene.

So far only the drawer allowed to set an optional content object. This
was now refactored into the control and now also the door and chest can
profit from the same logic.

In addition objects that were taken out of a drawer would disappear
again if the drawer was closed even if the objects were outside. This
needed to be handled with custom logic. Now there is a helper script
that will manage reparenting automatically.

In addition some code cleanup was done and where already applicable the
direction was extracted with the ultimate goal to have only one
direction enum.

Finally the button contains a small bug fix to define the force in a
much more reliable way.
files_changed: 025_Controls_Overview.unity; Utilities.meta; VRTK_ContentHandler.cs; VRTK_ContentHandler.cs.meta; VRTK_Button.cs; VRTK_Chest.cs; VRTK_Control.cs; VRTK_Control.cs.meta; VRTK_Door.cs; VRTK_Drawer.cs; VRTK_Knob.cs; VRTK_Lever.cs; VRTK_Slider.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Harvey Ball
message:
fix(Interaction): allow pause collisions on tracked objects

Previously, tracked objects did not pause collisions on grab due
to the code that calls the pause being inaccessible. This code has
now been moved so it is accessible for all grab mechanics.

author: Harvey Ball
message:
chore(events): ensure events are managed on enable and disable

The event listeners are now managed in `OnEnable` and they are removed
in `OnDisable` to ensure they are no longer registered when the object
is no longer active.
files_changed: VRTK_ControllerInteract_ListenerExample.cs; VRTK_WorldPointer.cs; VRTK_EventSystemVRInput.cs; VRTK_BasicTeleport.cs; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs; VRTK_ControllerActions.cs; VRTK_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs; VRTK_HeightAdjustTeleport.cs; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs; VRTK_InteractTouch.cs; VRTK_InteractUse.cs; VRTK_InteractableObject.cs; VRTK_PlayerClimb.cs; VRTK_PlayerPresence.cs

author: Robert Wetzold
message:
feat(Interaction): service pack for 3D controls

This patch is the result of adapting the controls further to a real game
scene.

The lever has been reworked, coding aligned with the other controls and
the detection is improved.

Auto-detection of door anchor points has been greatly improved by a new
calculation method. The nested door in 025 does not need the manual
hingejoint anymore.

All controls now support returning normalized values that range between
0-100%.

Buttons now support being moved at run-time by being connected to a
moving rigidbody.

Scene 025 has been cleaned up a bit and the texts now also show the
normalized value.
files_changed: 025_Controls_Overview.unity; ButtonAnimation.anim; ButtonAnimation.anim.meta; ButtonAnimation2.anim; ButtonAnimation2.anim.meta; ButtonWall 1.controller; ButtonWall 1.controller.meta; ButtonWall.controller; ButtonWall.controller.meta; MovingPanel2.controller; MovingPanel2.controller.meta; ControlReactor.cs; VRTK_Button.cs; VRTK_Chest.cs; VRTK_Control.cs; VRTK_Door.cs; VRTK_Drawer.cs; VRTK_Knob.cs; VRTK_Lever.cs; VRTK_Slider.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Harvey Ball
message:
fix(Interaction): remove unused triggerOnStaticObjects variable

The `triggerOnStaticObjects` variable is redundant due to how the
controller colliders and rigidbodies are now created.

author: Robert Wetzold
message:
fix(Interaction): make controller rigidbody unmovable

When no constraints are set on the controller rigidbody it will start
to move a and spin coming out of sync with the model and causing
erratic behaviour.

author: Harvey Ball
message:
fix(Controller): ensure rigidbody on not touching works on auto drop

The `Create Rigid Body When Not Touching` flag on the Interact Grab
script would only create a rigidbody on the grab event, so when an
item was being held but then dropped automatically (e.g. by banging it
into a wall and breaking the joint) but the grab button was still being
held down, the rigidbody would not activate.

This fix moves the logic into the Update routine so it constantly
checks for the state of the grab button and toggles the rigidbody
accordingly.

author: Robert Wetzold
message:
fix(Interaction): remove unused code in 3D button

Unity would show two warnings currently for the button.

author: Harvey Ball
message:
fix(Interaction): make force stop interactions wait for end of frame

Previously, it was possible to get the force stop interactions into an
infinite loop by calling `ForceStopTouching` or `ForceStopInteracting`
from within an event listener from the Stop Using event which would
in turn could emit the Stop Using event again and therefore getting
stuck in an infinite loop.

The fix now ensures that any interactable object force stop events
are done at the end of the frame giving the controller scripts time
to correctly clean up.

author: Harvey Ball
message:
feat(Structure): decouple SteamVR dependency from toolkit

Previously, the SteamVR Unity plugin was a hard dependency as the
scripts for the toolkit made multiple direct calls to SteamVR, OpenVR
and Valve.VR methods. This meant that using an alternative SDK would be
difficult or impossible to use.

This structural change moves all of the calls to SteamVR into an
SDK Bridge script and the toolkit now just makes generic calls to
this SDK Bridge. This means that as long as an SDK has a supporting
SDK Bridge script that supports the required methods then it can be
dropped into the toolkit and should just work.

author: Harvey Ball
message:
feat(Events): add unity events helper scripts for delegate events

The toolkit uses C# delegates to raise events, however, Unity Events
provide a nice inspector interface (but come at a performance cost) so
Unity Event helper scripts have been added that can be used to extend
the relevant script that is using a C# delegate to provide the benefit
of Unity Events but optionally to remove the requirement of the
performance overhead.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Teleport): extract teleport disable on headset collision

The ability to disable the teleport on headset collision has now been
extracted into it's own script to decouple the feature and also to
make it optional in case it's valid for teleporting to happen on
headset collision.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Teleport): remove static events in dash teleport

All of the other scripts use non-static events and require an instance
of an object to register events on it. Whilst items like the dash
teleport may only have one script in the scene, it's still more
appropriate to expect an instance because this way it ensures the
script is available on an object in the scene to register events
against.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(UIPointer): prevent central button flickering on hover

The `UI_CONTROL_OFFSET` const was previously removed as it was thought
it was no longer required. However, the offset does provide a mechanism
for preventing a discrepancy in hit distance that will cause a UI
element if centrally placed in the canvas to constantly hover enter and
immediately hover exit repeatidly. This causes the button flicker as
the button is constantly being hovered over and then out.

The fix is to put the `UI_CONTROL_OFFSET` back in but just set the
offset at a very low value so it stops the ui raycast at a blocking
object but will not trigger the discrepancy with the button flickering.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Structure): move prefab scripts within prefabs directory

The scripts that the prefabs rely on have now been moved into a
scripts directory within the prefabs directory as it makes more
sense to group these items together rather than keep the scripts
in the helper folder.

The radial menu scripts are still contained within the radial menu
directory in the `scripts/2D` directory.
files_changed: Scripts.meta; ConsoleViewer.cs; ConsoleViewer.cs.meta; FramsPerSecondViewer.cs; FramsPerSecondViewer.cs.meta; VRTK_ControllerTooltips.cs; VRTK_ControllerTooltips.cs.meta; VRTK_ObjectTooltip.cs; VRTK_ObjectTooltip.cs.meta

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Structure): rename prefab scripts to have vrtk_ prefix

To keep consistency, the prefab scripts have been updated to contain
the `VRTK_` prefix in the class name and the `FramesPerSecondViewer`
name has been corrected as it was originally `FramsPerSecondViewer`.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(ConsoleViewer): remove unnecessary struct

The `Log` struct was not being used and causing a compile warning.
It has now been deleted.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Structure): add namespace to radial menu prefab scripts

The radial menu scripts are decoupled from VRTK however, to prevent
clashes with other classes of the same name, it's easier to just
put these classes in to the `VRTK` namespace as they are required for
VRTK and not really envisaged to be used independently of the toolkit.

The Interactable Object Editor has also been moved to the `VRTK`
namespace for completeness.
files_changed: VRTK_InteractableObjectEditor.cs; RadialMenuInspector.cs; RadialButtonIcon.cs; RadialMenu.cs; UICircle.cs; CONTRIBUTING.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
refactor(SDK): use cached version of transform

Rather than using `GetComponent<Transform>` it's better to just use
`.transform` as unity caches this reference and it's quicker.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Locomotion): decouple touchpad walking from player presence

The Touchpad Walking script no longer requries the Player Presence
script to work as it can get the headset transform from the
Device Finder script. This also means the `GetHeadset()` method
in the Player Presence script can be removed as it's now obsolete.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Presence): replace collider with capsule collider

The original Box Collider on the Player Presence script has now
been replaced with a Capsule Collider which is a better option as it
resolves collisions in a more natural way, for instance a small bump
in the floor or a step will stop a box collider from moving, but
because of the shape of a capsule collider, the collision resolution
will move the capsule collider up the steps which gives for a more
natural feel.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Locomotion): add option to only touchpad walk on button press

A new option has been added to the Touchpad Walking script that
allows a button to be specified for enabling movement. Only when
that button is being pressed will the touchpad walking actually
move the user.

The Controller Events script has also been updated to allow for this
with a new public method that checks to see if a given button alias
is being pressed.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Teleport): ensure position change over tiny distance change

Previously, if the target position was very small then the lerp time
would be bigger than the elapsed time meaning the lerp would never
have a second pass and therefore the position was never updated.

This fix checks to see if the current position is not equal to the
target position after the lerp time has finished and if they're not
then it force moves the transform position to the target location.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
refactor(Pointer): remove helper gameobjects from bezier pointer

Previously, temporary helper game objects were created in the
Bezier Pointer script to plot the key positions for the bezier
pointer curve to be established. This is not required as the
destination of the raycast can be used to determine the points
required to polot the bezier curve.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(PolicyList): add ability to have multiple tag/script ignore checks

Previously, many of the classes utilised a single string to determine
whether something should be ignored by a tag or a script on the
component.

For example, the Teleport scripts could have a single tag or class name
provided to ignore any game objects containing that tag or named
component and treat it as an invalid teleport location.

This was very limiting as it only allowed for a single tag or class to
be specified and was always based on the items had to be in the ignore
list to be limited.

The new Tag Or Script Policy List script can now be added to a
component and have multiple tags or script name elements checked
against and can also have the operation set to `Ignore` to provide
the current behaviour, or be set to `Include` to only allow operations
on identifier matches.

This means for instance that the teleport script can be set up to
only teleport to areas that have a tag or script applied that is
in the list (rather than building a list of areas that cannot be
teleported to).

The existing Ignore With Tag Or Class string field has been left in
for legacy purposes and in case there are any unforseeable issues
with this new policy list. But it should be deprecated and then
removed in the future.
files_changed: VRTK_DestinationMarker.cs; VRTK_WorldPointer.cs; Utilities.cs; VRTK_EventSystemVRInput.cs; VRTK_BasicTeleport.cs; VRTK_HeadsetCollision.cs; VRTK_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs; VRTK_TagOrScriptPolicyList.cs; VRTK_TagOrScriptPolicyList.cs.meta; VRTK_UIPointer.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): remove limiting max angular velocity on throw

The Throw section of the Interact Grab script would limit the
`maxAngularVelocity` of the rigidbody to the current `angularVelocity`
of the thrown object, this is from the original SteamVR_TestThrow
script and assuming it is there to lock the rotation of the object
to the initial spin, but it would seem that an object should be
able to continue to spin faster if required.

Also, doing this breaks the `Track_Object` grab mechanic as it prevents
it from being rotated at a normal speed once dropped.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Components): simplify getting components and child components

The `GetComponentsInChildren` method will also return any types
found on the current object as well so it's not required to do a
`GetComponents` to affect the current object and then followed by
`GetComponentsInChildren` to affect the child objects.

`GetComponentsInChildren` is enough to deal with all current object
types and all child types as well. It's inefficient to make the
call twice and update the same object in both calls.

There are still occasions where a check to see if the item exists
on the current object using `GetComponent` is valid, because it
it a cheaper call to execute and if the object contains the
component then doing the more expensive `GetComponentInChildren`
is not required to be made.
files_changed: CurveGenerator.cs; Utilities.cs; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs; VRTK_InteractTouch.cs; VRTK_PlayerPresence.cs; VRTK_SimplePointer.cs

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): track every touching object instead of last one

The Interactable Object would only track the last controller to touch
it, which caused issues when both controllers touched the object at the
same time because if one controller was removed then the Interactable
Object's touched status would be set to null even though another
controller was still touching it.

The fix is to keep a `List<>` of all objects that are touching the
Interactable Object rather than just a reference to the last object
that touched it.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Pointer): prevent bezier pointer joint clipping on down cast

The Bezier Pointer would occasionally flicker between the valid/invalid
state specifically when hovering over a terrain due to the way the
forward cast joint position could be placed where when the down cast
happened it was already clipping through the target object meaning no
ray collision would occur.

The joint position already had an offset to move the joint back a
slight amount across the beam forward length, but this adjustment
also needed applying to `y` of the beam to ensure it always started
just above the target below.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): ensure multi-collider objects register touch properly

Previously, there was an issue with controller interaction touches
that meant if an object had multiple child colliders, it would register
a valid touch on one of the colliders and set the interactable
object associated with that collider as the `touchedObject`. However,
when another collider in the interactable object's collider set
was touched, it would register an trigger exit on the controller
touch and execute the `StopTouching` method only for 1 frame as the
next collider would then register a valid touch again keeping the
interactable object as the touched object.

This would cause a problem as as soon as `StopTouching` was called
it would also call `StopUsing` meaning if an object was being used
and the controller was being moved in a way that could cause the
collider trigger issue to occur, then the object would stop being
used until the use button was pressed again.

The new solution is to keep track of all of the colliders in a
game object and whenever the controller touches one of those colliders
it gets registered as an active collider, and when the controller
stops touching one of the valid colliders, it gets removed as an
active collider.

If the controller is no longer touching any of the object's colliders
then it is considered to no longer be touching the object. This way
means a more verbose and error free way of checking the object is
being touched or not.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(ControllerActions): remove redundant private variable

The `objectHighlighter` variable is now defined within the method as
it's not required for global scope, so the global definition has been
removed.

author: mattboy64
message:
feat(Climbing): climb release can height adjust or physics fall

Instead of assuming a physics based fall is required, the climbing
object now checks if we at or below ground level. If it is, it will
allow the VRTK_HeightAdjustTeleport object to move you up rather
than assuming you must enter a physics falling state.

The ground plane of example 37 (ClimbingFalling) now uses a box
collider on the ground. This should remove the falling through the
floor bug that was reported.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Pointer): separate play area cursor into own script

This commit brings some breaking changes to the World Pointer script.

The Play Area Cursor used to be part of the World Pointer script but
this meant the play area cursor was coupled to the pointer script and
meant that adding custon play area cursors would mean changing core
code.

A new `VRTK_PlayAreaCursor` script has now been added that can be
applied to the same game object that a World Poiinter component is
applied to. If the Play Area Cursor is applied then it works the same
way as previously, with the same options just moved into the new
script.
files_changed: 012_Controller_PointerWithAreaCollision.unity; 031_CameraRig_HeadsetGazePointer.unity; Setup_Scene_031.cs; VRTK_WorldPointer.cs; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs; VRTK_PlayAreaCursor.cs; VRTK_PlayAreaCursor.cs.meta; VRTK_SimplePointer.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Pointer): ensure custom pointer objects retain set material

Previously, the custom pointer objects were having their materials
overriden by the default pointer material which meant that any custom
objects didn't look correct.

This fix ensures that only the colour and emission colour on the
pointer objects is changed and not the material.

The inspector settings for the pointers has also had a bit of a tidy
up and headers added to make them easier to understand.

The Darken method from the Highlighter has also been moved to a public
static method in Utilities so it can be used in multiple places as it
now is.
files_changed: Blue.mat; Cyan.mat; Cyan.mat.meta; Green.mat; VRTK_DestinationMarker.cs; VRTK_WorldPointer.cs; CurveGenerator.cs; Utilities.cs; VRTK_MaterialColorSwapHighlighter.cs; VRTK_BezierPointer.cs; VRTK_PlayAreaCursor.cs; VRTK_SimplePointer.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Mike Labus
message:
feat(Interaction): lever attach to game object

Lever attaches to game object so that it is moveable with connected game
object. Previously, lever is unable to attach to game object and cannot
move without breaking.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Highlighter): clean up pre-existing outline clone objects

The Outline Object Copy Highlighter creates a clone object to use for
the highlighting. However, if the object to be highlighted changes
name after instantiation, then old object highlight cloned objects
can still exist for the previous name.

This fix, ensures on creating a highlight object clone that all
previous highlight object clones have been destroyed.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(AdapativeQuality): extract SteamVR call in editor to SDK Bridge

The Adaptive Quality custom editor script made a call directly to
SteamVR, this has now been separated out to an SDK Bridge call.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(SDK): move sdk specific code into sub file with only methods

The SDK bridge now is a dumb file that loads in an active SDK
(currently only SteamVR) which is a script that implements an SDK
interface (via abstract clas) to ensure the SDK meets the requirements
for the SDK Bridge to function correctly.

This will enable multiple SDK scripts to co-exist but can use Unity
environment variables to determine which SDK to load in.

The controller element paths have also been put into a method call
rather than a static variable as this will be more generic and
easier to customise for different SDKs.
files_changed: SDK_Base.cs; SDK_Base.cs.meta; SDK_SteamVR.cs; SDK_SteamVR.cs.meta; VRTK_SDK_Bridge.cs; VRTK_SDK_Bridge.cs.meta; VRTK_ControllerActions.cs; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs

author: Giovanni Paolo Vigan
message:
fix(UnityEvents): unregister listeners in OnDisable - resolves #642

fix(UnityEvents): unregister listeners in OnDisable - resolves #642

Changed += to -= in VRTK_BasicTeleport_UnityEvents.OnDisable().
Event handlers were added again instead of being removed #642

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Headset): remove need for scripts on headset

  > **Breaking Changes**

Previously, the scripts that required to be on the Headset object would
require placing on the correct object that the headset would finally
become. As SteamVR places the headset on a different game object in
Unity 5.3 to Unity 5.4 and above, it meant that the headset scripts
were cumbersome to use.

This change now just expects any headset related script to be placed
on the `[CameraRig]` prefab as it will look up the headset object
from the DeviceFinder and then apply any logic to the headset
game object rather than needing to directly be on that object.

This change makes it much easier to apply headset scripts as there is
no need to know which object to apply the script to.

The example scenes have been updated to use this new scheme and the
previous `Add_HeadsetCollisionFade` script that was present in some
example scenes has been removed as it no longer requires to do any
clever logic within the editor.
files_changed: VRTK_AdaptiveQualityEditor.cs; 011_Camera_HeadSetCollisionFading.unity; 012_Controller_PointerWithAreaCollision.unity; 017_CameraRig_TouchpadWalking.unity; 039_CameraRig_AdaptiveQuality.unity; Add_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs; Add_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs.meta; VRTK_AdaptiveQuality.cs; VRTK_HeadsetCollision.cs; VRTK_HeadsetCollisionFade.cs; VRTK_HeadsetFade.cs; VRTK_TeleportDisableOnHeadsetCollision.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(HipTracking): rename script to be inline with naming convention

  > **Breaking Changes**

The script naming convention doesn't use snake case for separating
words, instead it uses CamelCase. This means that `Hip_Tracking` is
incorrect and it has been renamed to `HipTracking` to ensure it
follows the convention.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(MonoBehaviour): rename Reset methods to not clash with Unity Reset

The Unity MonoBehaviour has a pre-defined method called `Reset` that is
executed whenever the user adds a component to a game object or clicks
the Reset menu option.

This means that any existing class that had a `Reset` method was
actually tying into the Unity editor Reset calls which is incorrect
as the state should not be reset on these actions.

The solution is to rename the relevant `Reset` methods in the VRTK
scripts to something else so they don't get called when the Unity
`Reset` method is executed.
files_changed: RC_Car.cs; RC_Car_Controller.cs; VRTK_ControllerTooltips.cs; VRTK_ObjectTooltip.cs; VRTK_BaseHighlighter.cs; VRTK_MaterialColorSwapHighlighter.cs; VRTK_OutlineObjectCopyHighlighter.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Highsight
message:
feat(Locomotion): add locomotion based on arm swing / head movement

A new locomotion method for VRTK based on Immersive Movement. This version
is feature complete, but still lacks polish and helpful features such as
events.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(DOCUMENTATION): auto generate docs for Move In Place

The Move In Place feature has now been added and the documentation
has been auto generated, plus a quick clean up of the code and
example scene hierarcy layout.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(UIPointer): remove UI Pointer artifacts from invalid canvas

If a canvas is set to invalid and `SetWorldCanvas` is called on it
then it will now clean that canvas of any artifacts that is set up
by the UI Pointer when it generates canvases.

This allows a canvas to have an ignore tag set on it at run time or
be taken out of World Space and then cleaned so the UI Pointer now
longer works with it.

Then it can also be enabled again by calling `SetWorldCanvas` again
when the canvas meets the criteria to be a valid canvas.

author: kjack9
message:
feat(MoveInPlace): add controller rotation control method

Add an additional method to direct locomotion for Motion In Place.

Controller Direction will average the rotation/direction of the two
controllers and use that value for movement.  If only one controller
is present, only that one value will be used.

author: Tim-PC\TimBookout
message:
feat(Interaction): alter velocity of thrown object based on distance

Currently when throwing grabbed object, the velocity is based on center
of steam controller. Change to increase velocity based on distance
object is attached to controller.

Example: Ball at end of stick will move at greater speed,
compared to where stick is being held.

Based on article at http://www.normalvr.com/blog/throwing-throw-down/

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
refactor(AdaptiveQuality): move timing calculations into its own class

This cleans up one of the bigger methods and makes reusing the timing
calculations easier for other settings that change dynamically.

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
refactor(AdaptiveQuality): move keyboard shortcuts into its own class

This is more consistent with how the other constants are used. It's now
also easier to change them if needed.

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
refactor(AdaptiveQuality): make property static

There's no need to have the same property on all instances, they can
share this one.

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
refactor(AdaptiveQuality): introduce a new class to represent an
adaptive setting

The `Setting` class represents a setting which is changed adaptively.
The class contains all the variables that are necessary for
bookkeeping.

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
fix(AdaptiveQuality): remove check for VR camera

The error help description is wrong since we no longer depend on
SteamVR thanks to the SDK bridge. Because of #661 checking for the
camera doesn't even make sense anymore so it is removed with this
change.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): ensure using state is set correctly after touch/grab

The Using state of an Interactable Object would get out of sync due to
the previous method of stopping an object's use method utilising a
co-routine at the end of the frame.

This was implemented due to StopTouching always being called even when
an object is grabbed. The fix is to remove the Coroutine as it causes
too many issues and to fix the issue at StopTouching by preventing
a stop touch event in the LateUpdate if the object is actually being
grabbed by the touching object, if it's being grabbed then it hasn't
stopped being touched in that instance.

This means that the Using action can get override correctly and no
artifacts are introduced at the end of the frame when stop using was
being called again, creating corruption with the Using State.

The toggle controller visibility has also been fixed by ensuring the
current controller visibility is stored and restored on grab and on
use events.

The `UsingAGrabbedObject` example scene has been updated to provide
more variations of grab and use to aid test interactions.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): add ability to utilise secondary controller grab

  > **Breaking Changes**

The `Is Swappable` parameter has now been removed from the interactable
object and is replaced with a new `Secondary Controller Grab Action`
that at the moment performs the same concept of either:

 * No action: When the second controller grabs the item doesn't swap.
 * Swap controller: When the second controller grabs the item swaps
 to the new controller hand.

The Interactable Object now also tracks the grab of both controllers,
the first controller to grab is considered holding the object and
the second controller to grab is considered to be influencing the
object or to have a specific action.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): add custom secondary grab action to scale objects

A new Custom Secondary Action has been added to the Interactable Object
that takes a new `SecondaryControllerGrabActions` script that defines
the behaviour of what should happen when a second controller grabs
an already grabbed object.

The first Secondary Controller Grab Action to be added is a basic
scale object that will cause the object to scale in the direction the
controller is being moved and it also has parameters on the custom
script to lock certain axis from being scaled.

A new example scene has been added that demonstrates scaling objects.
files_changed: VRTK_InteractableObjectEditor.cs; 043_Controller_SecondaryControllerActions.unity; 043_Controller_SecondaryControllerActions.unity.meta; SecondaryControllerGrabActions.meta; VRTK_AxisScaleGrabAction.cs; VRTK_AxisScaleGrabAction.cs.meta; VRTK_BaseGrabAction.cs; VRTK_BaseGrabAction.cs.meta; VRTK_InteractableObject.cs; VRTK_MoveInPlace.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md; EXAMPLES.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): add grab to pointer tip

A new parameter on the World Pointer can now be set that when a
pointer is set to `Interact With Objects = true` rather than on grab
snapping the object to the controller, it now uses the pointer tip
as the attach point.

The length of the pointer is locked at the point of grabbing so it's
not possible to bring the objects closer or move them further away
but a potential feature in the future could be custom public methods
on the pointer scripts that allow the manual entry of a pointer length
so it could be controller via an input of a controller.

author: gpvigano
message:
feat(Interaction): uniform scaling for secondary grab action

Add Uniform Scaling option to `VRTK_AxisScaleGrabAction`.

Refactor methods to reuse some code.

Change some `var` to the corresponding type to make the code more
readable.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(SnapDropZone): use highlight container for position

Rather than using the child highlight object, it's better to use the
highlight container for the end transition as this means the actual
highlight area can be different from the destination that the object
will snap into. Whilst, this may not be idea, it's at least better
to offer the option than force it to not be an option.

The position, rotation and size are also forced to the end position
after the co-routine has run to resolve any movement issues during
transition.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): remove redundant GetComponent/GetComponentInParent

The Interact Touch script would check to see if an Interactable
Object would exist on the current object then check it's parents
which is not required as GetComponentInParent already checks the
existing object as well.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): extract haptics out of interactable object

  > ** Breaking Changes **

The haptic feedback on the interactable object has now been extracted
into it's own script that performs the haptic feedback.

This cleans up optional parameters on the interactable object and
separates the responsibility of the operation into it's own script.
files_changed: VRTK_InteractableObjectEditor.cs; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs; VRTK_InteractHaptics.cs; VRTK_InteractHaptics.cs.meta; VRTK_InteractTouch.cs; VRTK_InteractUse.cs; VRTK_InteractableObject.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): remove global touch highlight option

  > ** Breaking Changes **

The Global Touch Highlight Color option on the Interact Touch script
has now been removed as it is somewhat redundant as each Interactable
Object can have a colour set on it individually or multiple objects
can be selected and have the colour set on all of them together.

Having similar options in multiple places causes confusion with what
overrides what.

The Interactable Object also now just has a Touch Highlight Color
option and no longer has a toggle. If there is no highlight colour
required then the colour should be set to `Color.clear` which is
`#00000000` as this will then be ignored when attempting to highlight.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): extract controller visibility to own script

  > ** Breaking Changes **

The Interactable Object now no longer deals with the controller
visibility state and there is also no global controller visibility
state on touch, grab and use of an interactable object.

The new Interact Controller Appearance script is now applied to any
Interactable Object Game Object that requires the controller to be
toggled visible/hidden when the controller touches/grabs/uses the
object the script is applied to.

This separates out optional logic, ensures no global overrides need
to be handled and cleans up the Interactable Object script.

The example scenes that used the controller visibility settings
have been updated to use the new script.
files_changed: VRTK_InteractableObjectEditor.cs; 008_Controller_UsingAGrabbedObject.unity; 014_Controller_SnappingObjectsOnGrab.unity; 016_Controller_HapticRumble.unity; 021_Controller_GrabbingObjectsWithJoints.unity; 023_Controller_ChildOfControllerOnGrab.unity; 026_Controller_ForceHoldObject.unity; 032_Controller_CustomControllerModel.unity; BasicArrow.prefab; VRTK_InteractControllerAppearance.cs; VRTK_InteractControllerAppearance.cs.meta; VRTK_InteractGrab.cs; VRTK_InteractTouch.cs; VRTK_InteractUse.cs; VRTK_InteractableObject.cs; DOCUMENTATION.md

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Interaction): combine secondary grab actions into one parameter

  > ** Breaking Changes **

Previously, the secondary grab action was a drop down with a custom
option allowing to provide a grab action script.

This has now been simplified into one field which is simply the
ability to provide a secondary grab action script. There is also
now a Swap Controller grab action script that provides the same
functionality that the `Swap Controller` option provided in the
previous incarnation of the setup.

Providing no script is the same as the previous `No Action` setting.

If no script is provided and a secondary grab action script is present
on the object, then it will be used at runtime.

The custom Interactable Object editor script has now also been removed
as it is no longer required as the Interactable Object script is much
more simplified with all optional settings now extracted into their
own scripts.

  > ** Breaking Changes

A number of the methods in SharedMethods were very specific to scripts
that already existed so it is more appropraite for those scripts to
contain the static methods rather than just having them dumped in the
SharedMethods script.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Pointer): ensure controller is valid before removing event handlers

The event handler removal in the OnDisable can cause a crash if the
controller object is no longer available. This fix ensures the event
handlers only get removed if the controller object is still valid.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(tag_or_class_string): remove tag_or_class string option

  > ** Breaking Changes **

Previously, a number of scripts contained a string parameter that would
be used to denote a Tag Or Script that should be ignored by the
relevant script. For example, the teleporter script would ignore any
objects that had the given string for a tag or an attached script.

As the Tag or Script Policy List script handles all of this
functionality, it means that the string parameter is largely obsolete
and should be removed to keep the functionality within the Policy
List script.

All of the example scenes have been updated to utilise Policy Lists
now instead of a given script or string name.

feat(PolicyList): add support for layers and rename script

  > ** Breaking Changes **

The TagOrScriptPolicyList has now been renamed simply to Policy List
as it also now allows for checking of object layers and it is better
to simplify the name rather than futher complicate it.

The Policy List also has a custom editor class that allows multiple
selections from the dropdown to choose the most appropraite selection
when checking for inclusion or exclusion.

The relevant scripts that utilise a policy list have also been updated
so their variable names simply refer to a policy list.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(SDK): require all sdks to adhere to specific interface

  > ** Breaking Changes **

The SDKs now must adhere to the appropriate interface by implementing
all methods outlined in the relevant interface.

The SteamVR SDKs will now also return back to the Fallback SDK if
the scripting define symbol for SteamVR is not found
(`VRTK_SDK_STEAMVR`).

A spelling error in the SDK_InterfaceController has been amended as
`ControllerElements` was spelt incorrectly, this enum has also been
renamed now to `VRTK_ControllerElements` and has been moved to the
top level of the VRTK namespace.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Structure): remove erroneous semi colons

Some lines had double semi colons which isn't required.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(SDK): remove interface and impose contract with abstract class

  > ** Breaking Changes **

The SDK interfaces have now been removed and the Base classes are now
responsible for enforcing the concrete SDK implemented methods.

All public SDK methods are now abstract in the Base class to ensure
they have to be implemented by any concrete SDK.

The Base classes may also contain protected methods to share common
logic to any concrete implementation but this change now means it
is easier to know which methods need to be implemented when writing
an SDK.

Some of the public enums have been moved into the Base SDK classes
as they make more sense to have them located within the SDK and as
such any references to these enums has been updated to point to the
SDK abstract class.

author: Victor Hagsand
message:
feat(SDK): add simulator

Add new Simulator SDK for using mouse instead of controllers.
This will allow for using the mouse to move and rotate virtual
"hands" and allowing the developer to grab, use and in different
ways manipulating objects without the need of a VR controller.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
refactor(SDKManager): consolidate selected SDK checks

The selected SDK checks have now been cleaned up and use a new
`VRTK_SDKDetails` class to hold the relevant SDK details meaning
it is cleaner to read in the code and easier to add new SDK details
in the future.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(SpringLever): rename script to conform with naming convention

The `VRTK_Spring_Lever` script has been renamed to `VRTK_SpringLever`
removing the additional underscore as this does not adhere to the
naming convention used by other scripts.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(SDK): rename vr simulator prefab to more meaningful name

The VR Simulator prefab has now been renamed to `VRSimulatorCameraRig`
to give it a more meaningful name and to fall in line with how other
VR SDKs name their Camera Rig prefabs.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): prevent controller becoming visible after use

There was a race condition where if an object's visibility was set
to hide on grab then after it was used it would be automatically
visibile again even if it was still being grabbed.

The code in the Interact Use that was checking to see if the object
should be forced visible again after use should never have been
called as a using object was always required when unuse is executed.

Also, removed a couple of old private methods that no longer get
used in Interact Touch and Interact Use.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(AdaptiveQuality): remove sdk error when using debug visualisation

If the debug visualisation parameter was ticked and the scene was being
run from the Unity editor, then the `OnValidate` method would run
before the `Awake` method for the SDKManager meaning no SDK was set.

This caused the fallback SDK to be used and therefore throwing the
error about the Fallback SDK being used.

The fix just checks to see if the SDKManager instance has been created
before trying to access something with the Device Finder.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(UIPointer): ensure event input pointers list is managed correctly

Previously, whenever a UIPointer was initialised it would get added to
the Event Input pointers list, but it could end up being added multiple
times to the same list as no checking was done to see if it already
existed within the list and it was also not removed from the list when
the UIPointer was disabled.

This fix ensures the list is correctly managed and also caches the
event system and event system input to prevent them from being re-found
each time a pointer is enabled.

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
refactor(SDK): use OpenVR provided invalid index

The VRTK SteamVR SDK used `uint.MaxValue` to check if a controller
index is out of bounds. This change makes sure the OpenVR provided
constant for the first invalid tracked device index is used instead.
`uint.MaxValue` is still used for everything that is VRTK API since it
is used to signal an invalid or missing index.

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
fix(SDK): support SteamVR Plugin version 1.2.0

The SteamVR Plugin has been updated to version 1.2.0 which removed the
method `SteamVR_Util.Event.Listen`. Since it has not been deprecated it
now causes errors to be thrown in VRTK as this method was used within
the SteamVR Controller SDK.

This fix updates the code to use the new API when found, otherwise it
will fall back to the previous API.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(velocity_tracking): move velocity tracking to device finder

The Velocity tracking on the controllers was originally done in
Controller Events, but this is not the best place for it as velocity
retrieval is not really an event. The Velocity and Angular Velocity
retrieval methods have now been moved to the Device Finder script.

The Controller SDK Update routine has also been moved out of
Controller Events and into the Tracked Controller script as this script
is always available in the scene.

An addition of a Tracked Headset script has also been added that runs
an Update routine for the headset within the SDK mimicking the
functionality of the Tracked Controller update.

The methods in the Controller Events script are still in place but have
been deprecated (and removed from the documentation) and now all they
do is pass through the call to the Device Finder.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Locomotion): add speed multiplier button to touchpad walking

The Touchpad Walking script now has an option to press an additional
button to activate a speed multiplier which if is set to a number
above 1f then it will speed up the movement, however if it is set
below 1f then it will slow movement down.

author: reznovVR
message:
feat(Locomotion): add improved touchpad movement script

The script adds the ability to move and rotate the play area and the
player by using the touchpad.

Vertical axis movement types include:
- regular smooth sliding (walking)
- warping, which instantly moves the player forward at a fixed distance

Horizontal axis movement types include:
- smooth sliding (strafing)
- smooth rotation
- snap rotation, which instantly rotates the player at a fixed angle
- warping, which instantly moves the player sideways (instant strafing)

Additionally it's possible to enable direction flip feature which
allows the user to do an instant 180 degree turn by pressing the
touchpad down.

Different movement types can be split across the controllers by
having one script per hand side and with the desired options.
Warp and snap rotate options may provide more comfortable experience
for some and blink effect can be used to soften the movement.
Snap rotate and flip direction options can be useful with teleport
scripts for seated experiences and for people using front facing
camera setups (Oculus default, PSVR).

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
chore(Locomotion): switch touchpad movement delegate to struct payload

The Touchpad Movement script now uses a struct for it's payload to be
inline with the other scripts way of working and also so the auto
document generation works correctly.

The documentation has also been generated and included in this commit.

author: Christopher - Marcel Bddecker
message:
fix(AdaptiveQuality): ensure debug visualization moves with headset

The debug visualization was not correctly parented to the headset. This
change makes sure to only attach at the appropriate moment to fix the
problem.

author: Benedikt Reiser
message:
feat(Highlighters): add highlighter using MPB for material swap

- implemented a Material Property Block highlighter as an alternative
  to the default color swap highlighter
- works for material instances as well
- renamed highlighter to match the scheme of the other highlighters
- all credit for the implementation  of the highlighter goes to
  fight4dream: https://github.com/fight4dream
- original implementation: https://github.com/fight4dream/VRTK/commit/bbc50a75d8c5b64b128877e79eff31b02c7f8cdf

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): provide more natural door control

  > **Breaking Changes**

The 3D Door Control now uses the RotatorTrack grab mechanic to provide
a more natural door operation. The `Snapping` inspector parameter has
now been replaced with a float to determine the snap distance the door
has to be from being in a closed state before it snaps shut.

It is also possible now to provide the friction value that the door has
when it is being grabbed and moved, and the friction when it is not
being grabbed. A high grabbed friction gives a less bouncey feel and a
low ungrabbed friction allows the door to swing freely to allow for
slamming shut.

Another tweak is it is possible to apply the interactable object to the
entire door object rather than just the handle, which can be useful
for small doors such as cupboards, where it's desired to grab the door
to close it.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
fix(Interaction): rebuild slider control to use joints

  > **Breaking Changes**

The old Slider 3D Control used world positions to determine the slider
placement, this caused issues when the slider was attached to something
and it also meant it could not be attached to something that moved
around.

Another fundamental issue occured when the slider was placed along a
world z-axis as the world positions would cause the slider to
constantly flicker between the two extreme values.

The solution has been to re-write the slider and use a configurable
joint to allow the slider to move across the axis. It is also required
now that the min/max points of the slider are provided as a collider
which also keeps the slider from exceeding the values using game
physic collisions.

The slider snap is also resolved with physics now using the spring
position on the joint.

It is also now possible to attach the slider to a moving object and
it will still function.

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
refactor(Controls): improve code to meet coding guidelines

The code for the 3D Controls has been refactored to improve it's
readability and to adhere closer to the coding guidelines.

Variable names have been updated to be more human readable and
re-declaring global variable names in local scope has been removed
in case of any unwanted mutation side effects. Any variables that
were previously global that did not require to be global have now
been moved into local scope.

The correct use of line breaks with bracket lines and enums has also
been added where necessary.

Certain defined static defined variables should actually be defined
as constants so they have been updated where required.
files_changed: VRTK_ContentHandler.cs; VRTK_Button.cs; VRTK_Chest.cs; VRTK_Control.cs; VRTK_Door.cs; VRTK_Drawer.cs; VRTK_Knob.cs; VRTK_Lever.cs; VRTK_SpringLever.cs

author: Theston E. Fox
message:
feat(Controls): implement c# delegates in place of unity events

The 3D Controls now have c# delegates by default as the events whilst
the previous hard coded Unity events have been deprecated (and will
be removed in the future).

This is to bring them in line with other scripts in the system and to
reduce the overhead of Unity events if so required. The 3D Controls
and the 3D Button control also come with complimentary Unity Event
helpers that enable unity events to be used with the controls still
if so required.
